Rather what it did indicate, or state very clearly, was that if you had someone who was mentally ill and because of their mental illness was, in fact, involved in a lot of problems, behavioral problems, that the environment in the security housing unit could exacerbate that.
As a result of that, the federal court, Judge Henderson, ruled that what we would have to do is two things.

One, those inmates that were diagnosed with a serious mental illness could not be housed in that particular security housing unit, had to be placed in a different area of the institution and provided psychiatric services.
And in addition to that, he required that we be on the lookout.

And so we have a cadre of psychologists and licensed clinical social workers that are assigned specifically to the security housing unit who make rounds, like a doctor would at hospitals, interviewing the men, talking to the men - also, the training of correctional staff to be able to identify, from a rudimentary perspective, when an inmate may be having some problems and make those immediate referrals.
